texts.definition: Games which are one by achieving a required game state which ends gameplay.
markups: <style="Definition">Games which are one by achieving a required game state which ends gameplay.</style>

A majority of games are designed so they end at some point. Those that reward a player by letting them win by doing so use a <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> design solution (the typical other solution with winners is to end gameplay and then determine the winner).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> is won by checkmating one's opponent (or making him or her surrender) while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> ends as soon as a player can show that he or she has 10 points. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Racing%20Games">Racing Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Formula%20D">Formula D</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hare%20and%20Tortoise">Hare and Tortoise</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pachisi">Pachisi</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Snakes%20and%20Ladders">Snakes and Ladders</link></style> can be seen as weak examples of <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> since only the winner may actually have gameplay ended if the other players continue playing to see what positions they got; two-player versions of these games are however strong examples.

Many games with narratives, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%20series">Half-Life series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style>, end with a "victory" when the player has completed the last challenges and been told the end of the story.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> is in practice designed a goal which ends gameplay and declares the player who reached the goal the winner. Unlike <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> can be applied both to <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>.

General examples, to the level that they are patterns, which support <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> is <style="Link"><link="last-man-standing">Last Man Standing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>, and games where one wins by having a certain <style="Link"><link="scores">Score</link></style>. The specific choices made regarding the pattern heavily affect how a <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> plays out if a game has such a gameplay phase.

One design consideration that needs to be taken for the pattern is however if several players can, or should be allowed to, end gameplay simultaneously. <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> can be used as <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> if this is the case and <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style> are unwanted.

Due to its definition, <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> is incompatible with <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style>. However, if <style="Link"><link="speedending">Speedending</link></style> is possible in the latter the combination of these can result in players <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> (if they judged the game state correctly and managed to end the game instance quickly enough).

<style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalties</link></style> is not typically compatible with <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> since the latter is a <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> rather than a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> causes <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style> for players and in many cases <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> when this is close to occurring. The pattern can be used to let players have a chance of ending <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style> prematurely by winning, but can also be used to designate <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style> or a <style="Link"><link="game-system-player">Game System Player</link></style> to win if no player has won when time has run out. <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> creates <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> since who wins a game is typically the largest closure in a game instance and <style="CurrentLink">Winning by Ending Gameplay</style> puts this after the end of gameplay,
<style="Link"><link="speedending">Speedending</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style>
